messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Branching Bisimilarity for Processes with Time-outs

Paper Section Text:

Moreover, Pâ†’(Î±)Pâ€²fragmentsPfragments(Î±)â†’Pâ€²P\xrightarrow{\mbox{\tiny\rm(}\alpha\mbox{\tiny\rm)}}P^{\prime} denotes that either Î±=Ï„fragmentsÎ±Ï„\alpha=\tau and P=Pâ€²fragmentsPPâ€²P=P^{\prime}, or Pâ†’Î±Pâ€²fragmentsPğ›¼â†’Pâ€²P\xrightarrow{\alpha}P^{\prime}. Furthermore, paths are sequences of connected transitions and âŸ¹âŸ¹\Longrightarrow is the reflexive-transitive closure of â†’Ï„ğœâ†’\xrightarrow{\tau}. The set of initial actions of a process Pâˆˆâ„™fragmentsPPP\in\mathbb{P} is â„(P):={Î±âˆˆAÏ„âˆ£Pâ†’Î±}fragmentsI(P)assign{Î±Ağœâˆ£Pğ›¼â†’}\mathcal{I}(P):=\{\alpha\in A_{\tau}\mid P{\xrightarrow{\alpha}}\}. Here Pâ†’Î±fragmentsPğ›¼â†’P{\xrightarrow{\alpha}} means that there is a Qğ‘„Q with Pâ†’Î±QfragmentsPğ›¼â†’QP\xrightarrow{\alpha}Q. A branchingÂ reactive bisimulation is a symmetric111meaning that (P,Q)âˆˆâ„›â‡”(Q,P)âˆˆâ„›fragments(P,Q)â„›â‡”(Q,P)â„›(P,Q)\in\R\Leftrightarrow(Q,P)\in\R and (P,X,Q)âˆˆâ„›â‡”(Q,X,P)âˆˆâ„›fragments(P,X,Q)â„›â‡”(Q,X,P)â„›(P,X,Q)\in\R\Leftrightarrow(Q,X,P)\in\R relation â„›âŠ†(â„™Ã—â„™)âˆª(â„™Ã—ğ’«(A)Ã—â„™)fragmentsâ„›(PP)(Pğ’«(A)P)\R\subseteq(\mathbb{P}\times\mathbb{P})\cup(\mathbb{P}\times\Pow(A)\times\mathbb{P}) such that, for all P,Qâˆˆâ„™fragmentsP,QPP,Q\in\mathbb{P} and XâŠ†AfragmentsXAX\subseteq A, if â„›(P,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q)\R(P,Q) then if Pğ‘ƒP with Î±âˆˆAÏ„fragmentsÎ±Ağœ\alpha\in A_{\tau} then there is a path QâŸ¹Q1fragmentsQâŸ¹Q1Q\Longrightarrow Q_{1} with â„›(P,Q1)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q1)\R(P,Q_{1}) and â„›(Pâ€²,Q2)fragmentsâ„›(Pâ€²,Q2)\R(P^{\prime},Q_{2}), for all YâŠ†AfragmentsYAY\subseteq A, â„›(P,Y,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,Y,Q)\R(P,Y,Q); if â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q) then if Pâ†’Ï„Pâ€²fragmentsPğœâ†’Pâ€²P\xrightarrow{\tau}P^{\prime} then there is a path QâŸ¹Q1fragmentsQâŸ¹Q1Q\Longrightarrow Q_{1} with â„›(P,X,Q1)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q1)\R(P,X,Q_{1}) and â„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2)fragmentsâ„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2)\R(P^{\prime},X,Q_{2}), if Pğ‘ƒP with aâˆˆXfragmentsaXa\in X then there is a path QâŸ¹Q1fragmentsQâŸ¹Q1Q\Longrightarrow Q_{1} with â„›(P,X,Q1)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q1)\R(P,X,Q_{1}) and â„›(Pâ€²,Q2)fragmentsâ„›(Pâ€²,Q2)\R(P^{\prime},Q_{2}), if â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset then there is a path QâŸ¹Q0fragmentsQâŸ¹Q0Q\Longrightarrow Q_{0} with â„›(P,Q0)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q0)\R(P,Q_{0}), if â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset and Pğ‘ƒP then there is a path Q=:Q0âŸ¹Q1fragmentsQfragments:Q0âŸ¹Q1Q\mathrel{=:}Q_{0}\Longrightarrow Q_{1} with r>0fragmentsr0r>0, such that âˆ€iâˆˆ[0,râˆ’1],â„›(P,X,Q2i)âˆ§â„(Q2i+1)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsfor-alli[0,r1],â„›(P,X,Qfragments2i)I(Qfragments2i1)(X{Ï„})\forall i\in[0,r{-}1],\R(P,X,Q_{2i})\wedge\mathcal{I}(Q_{2i+1})\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset and â„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2r)fragmentsâ„›(Pâ€²,X,Qfragments2r)\R(P^{\prime},X,Q_{2r}), if Pï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsPğœâ†’P\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} then there is a path QâŸ¹Q0ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQâŸ¹Q0ğœâ†’Q\Longrightarrow Q_{0}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau}. For P,Qâˆˆâ„™fragmentsP,QPP,Q\mathbin{\in}\mathbb{P}, if there exists a branchingÂ reactive bisimulation â„›â„›\R with â„›(P,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q)\R(P,Q) (resp.Â â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q)) then Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q are said to be branchingÂ reactive bisimilar (resp.Â branchingÂ Xğ‘‹X-bisimilar), which is denoted Pâ†”Â¯brQfragmentsPfragmentsÂ¯â†”fragmentsbrQP\mathrel{\,\raisebox{2.15277pt}{$\underline{\makebox[6.99997pt]{\raisebox{-1.0pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\leftrightarrow$}}}$}\,_{br}\!}Q (resp.Â Pâ†”Â¯XbrQfragmentsPfragmentsÂ¯â†”ğ‘‹fragmentsbrQP\mathrel{\,\raisebox{2.15277pt}{$\underline{\makebox[6.99997pt]{\raisebox{-1.0pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\leftrightarrow$}}}$}\,^{X}_{br}\!}Q). To build the above definition, the definition of a strong reactive bisimulation [ref]11 was modified in a branching manner . Intuitively, a triplet â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q) affirms that Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q behave similarly when the environment allows (only) the set of actions in Xğ‘‹X to occur, whereas a couple â„›(P,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q)\R(P,Q) says that Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q behave in the same way when the environment has been triggered to change. As said before, the environment can be seen as a system executed in parallel while enforcing the synchronisation of all visible actions. Clause 1 captures the scenario of a triggered environment: if Pğ‘ƒP can perform a visible or invisible action then Qğ‘„Q has to be able to match it; and the environment can settle on a set Yğ‘ŒY of allowed actions at any moment. Time-outs are not considered because these can occur only when the system idles, and idling can happen only when the environment has stabilised on a set of allowed actions. One might notice that, in [ref]11, the first clause was only required for invisible actions. However, there the case Î±â‰ Ï„fragmentsÎ±Ï„\alpha\neq\tau is actually implied by the other clauses. If in our definition Clause 1.a were restricted to invisible actions then â†”Â¯brfragmentsÂ¯â†”fragmentsbr\mathrel{\,\raisebox{2.15277pt}{$\underline{\makebox[6.99997pt]{\raisebox{-1.0pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\leftrightarrow$}}}$}\,_{br}\!} would not be a congruence for the parallel operator, as shown in Appendix A. Clause 2 depicts the scenario of an environment allowing Xğ‘‹X. Ï„ğœ\tau-transitions have to be matched since the environment cannot disallow them, and their execution does not trigger the environment to change. Visible actions have to be matched only if they are allowed, and their execution triggers the environment. Triggering the environment or not explains why Clause 2a matches Q2fragmentsQ2Q_{2} in a triplet and Clause 2b in a couple. If Pğ‘ƒP idles (i.e.Â â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset) then the environment can be triggered, thus, Qğ‘„Q has to be able to instantaneously reach a state Q0fragmentsQ0Q_{0} related to Pğ‘ƒP in a triggered environment.222By LemmaÂ 2.11.4 we can even choose Q0fragmentsQ0Q_{0} such that Q0ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQ0ğœâ†’Q_{0}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau}, so that â„(Q0)=â„(P)fragmentsI(Q0)I(P)\mathcal{I}(Q_{0})=\mathcal{I}(P). If Pğ‘ƒP idles and has an outgoing time-out transition then Qğ‘„Q has to be able to match it in a branching manner. This involves Qğ‘„Q performing any sequence of Ï„ğœ\tau and tt{\rm t}-transitions, such that all states encountered prior to the last optional tt{\rm t} are related to Pğ‘ƒP.333Clause 2.d requires this only for states of the form Q2ifragmentsQfragments2iQ_{2i} with iâˆˆ[0,râˆ’1]fragmentsi[0,r1]i\in[0,r{-}1], but by LemmaÂ 2.11.1 it holds for all of them. Clause 2.c further implies that in Clause 2.d we have â„›(P,Q2i+1)fragmentsâ„›(P,Qfragments2i1)\R(P,Q_{2i+1}) for all iâˆˆ[0,râˆ’1]fragmentsi[0,r1]i\in[0,r{-}1]. Lastly, a stability respecting clause [ref]7 was added for practical reasons. In Appendix A, an example shows that without it â†”Â¯brfragmentsÂ¯â†”fragmentsbr\mathrel{\,\raisebox{2.15277pt}{$\underline{\makebox[6.99997pt]{\raisebox{-1.0pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\leftrightarrow$}}}$}\,_{br}\!} would not even be an equivalence. For the important class of divergence-free systems, without infinite sequences Q0â†’Ï„Q1â†’Ï„â€¦fragmentsQ0ğœâ†’Q1ğœâ†’â€¦Q_{0}\xrightarrow{\tau}Q_{1}\xrightarrow{\tau}\dots, Clause 2.e is easily seen to be redundant. Let â„›â„›\R be a branchingÂ reactive bisimulation. If â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q), Pï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsPğœâ†’P\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} and QâŸ¹Qâ€²fragmentsQâŸ¹Qâ€²Q\Longrightarrow Q^{\prime} then also â„›(P,X,Qâ€²)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Qâ€²)\R(P,X,Q^{\prime}). If â„›(P,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q)\R(P,Q) or â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q), Pï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsPğœâ†’P\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} and Qï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQğœâ†’Q\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} then â„(Q)=â„(P)fragmentsI(Q)I(P)\mathcal{I}(Q)=\mathcal{I}(P). If â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q), â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset and Qï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQğœâ†’Q\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} then â„›(P,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q)\R(P,Q). If â„›(P,X,Q)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q)\R(P,X,Q) and â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset then there is a path QâŸ¹Q0fragmentsQâŸ¹Q0Q\Longrightarrow Q_{0} with â„›(P,Q0)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q0)\R(P,Q_{0}), Q0ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQ0ğœâ†’Q_{0}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} and â„(Q0)=â„(P)fragmentsI(Q0)I(P)\mathcal{I}(Q_{0})=\mathcal{I}(P). This is an immediate consequence of the symmetric counterpart of Clause 2.a (where Qğ‘„Q takes a Ï„ğœ\tau-step).
When that clause yields PâŸ¹P1fragmentsPâŸ¹P1P\Longrightarrow P_{1} we have P2=PfragmentsP2PP_{2}=P. This is a direct consequence of Clause 1.a or 2.b and its symmetric counterpart. By Clause 2.e there is path QâŸ¹Q0fragmentsQâŸ¹Q0Q\Longrightarrow Q_{0} with Q0ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQ0ğœâ†’Q_{0}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau}. By Claim 1 of this lemma, â„›(P,X,Q0)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q0)\R(P,X,Q_{0}). Thus, by Clause 2.c there is a path Q0âŸ¹Q1fragmentsQ0âŸ¹Q1Q_{0}\mathbin{\Longrightarrow}Q_{1} with â„›(P,Q1)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q1)\R(P,Q_{1}), but Q1=Q0=QfragmentsQ1Q0QQ_{1}\mathop{=}Q_{0}\mathop{=}Q since Qï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQğœâ†’Q\!\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau}. By Clause 2.e there is path QâŸ¹Q0fragmentsQâŸ¹Q0Q\Longrightarrow Q_{0} with Q0ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQ0ğœâ†’Q_{0}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau}. By Claim 1 of this lemma, â„›(P,X,Q0)fragmentsâ„›(P,X,Q0)\R(P,X,Q_{0}). That â„(Q0)=â„(P)fragmentsI(Q0)I(P)\mathcal{I}(Q_{0})=\mathcal{I}(P) and â„›(P,Q0)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q0)\R(P,Q_{0}) follows by Claims 2 and 3 of this lemma. DefinitionÂ 2.1 enables us to elide some time-outs. Using the process algebra notation to be formally introduced in SectionÂ 4, the processes a.t.b.0fragmentsa.t.b.0a.{\rm t}.b.0 and a.t.t.b.0fragmentsa.t.t.b.0a.{\rm t}.{\rm t}.b.0 (as well as a.t.Ï„.t.b.0fragmentsa.t.Ï„.t.b.0a.{\rm t}.\tau.{\rm t}.b.0) are branchingÂ reactive bisimilar. Both require an unquantified positive but finite amount of rest between the actions ağ‘a and bğ‘b. To support this example, Clause 2.d of DefinitionÂ 2.1 must allow a single time-out transition of one process to be matched by either zero or multiple time-outs of the other. An alternative definition, treating time-outs more like visible transitions, is obtained by replacing Clause 2.d by if â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset and Pğ‘ƒP then there is a path QâŸ¹Q1fragmentsQâŸ¹Q1Q\Longrightarrow Q_{1} with â„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2)fragmentsâ„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2)\R(P^{\prime},X,Q_{2}). Requiring that the matching time-out is executable (i.e.Â â„(Q1)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(Q1)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(Q_{1})\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset) is not necessary here, as it is implied by the other clauses. Indeed, LemmaÂ 2.11.3, which is not affected by changing Clause 2.d, implies the existence of a path QâŸ¹Q1ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQâŸ¹Q1ğœâ†’Q\Longrightarrow Q_{1}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau} such that â„›(P,Q1)fragmentsâ„›(P,Q1)\R(P,Q_{1}) and â„(Q1)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(Q1)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(Q_{1})\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset. Since Q1ï¼â†’Ï„fragmentsQ1ğœâ†’Q_{1}\,\not\!\xrightarrow{\tau}, â„(P)âˆ©(Xâˆª{Ï„})=âˆ…fragmentsI(P)(X{Ï„})\mathcal{I}(P)\cap(X\cup\{\tau\})=\emptyset and Pğ‘ƒP, Clause 2d yields Q1fragmentsQ1Q_{1} with â„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2)fragmentsâ„›(Pâ€²,X,Q2)\R(P^{\prime},X,Q_{2}). This version of the definition has been studied  and has properties similar to â†”Â¯brfragmentsÂ¯â†”fragmentsbr\mathrel{\,\raisebox{2.15277pt}{$\underline{\makebox[6.99997pt]{\raisebox{-1.0pt}[0.0pt][0.0pt]{$\leftrightarrow$}}}$}\,_{br}\!}â€‰, which are recapped in Appendix B. In , branching bisimilarity is expressed in multiple equivalent ways. For practical purposes, our definition uses the semi-branching format, which is equivalent to the branching format thanks to the following lemma.
